moves.2... exf4 3. Nf3 d5: I knew how to play this opening well, but I lack the experience in playing it.
moves.4. exd5 Nf6: Qxd5 is bad here due to Nc3, getting white a tempo.
moves.5. Bc4: Normally the response in Nc3 or c4. If c4, then c6 and black retains an advantage.
moves.5... c6: I played incorrectly and if the pawn were taken, the effect of the King's Gambit would activate. Note that this opening is to start a queen side pawn storm.
moves.6... cxd5 7. Bb3 Be6 8. Qe1 Bd6: I protect the f5 pawn earlier because it looks like a better time saving move. Once the white bishop recaptures on f4, then the pawn storm is dominant.
moves.9... Nc6 10. c3 O-O 11. Nbd2: Somewhat of a bad move here. I gain a  tempo after Ng4, as if the knight won't leave, I control e3, where my knight is said to be as powerful as a rook.
moves.11... Ng4 12. Nb1: Controlling e3 again. I get a 2 move tempo, so I continue positionally advancing.
moves.14. Nxh4 Na5 15. Nd2 Ne3 16. Re1: Here came the blunder. If you are under 1400, think about my next move.
moves.18. Bd2 Nxa1 19. Rxa1 b6 20. Rf1 a5: The attack is basically over here, so I can begin my own. The f4 pawn is indirectly defended.
moves.21. Bxf4 Bxf4 22. Rxf4 g5: White resigned here. The lessons here are to outpost your knight, mainly on the 5th and 6th ranks, dominate weak squares of the enemy, and always look for defenses like shown on the position right now.
